revision.text:
{{Infobox spaceflight | name = Intelsat V F-2 → Intelsat 502 | image = | image_caption = | mission_type = [[Communications satellite|Communication]] | operator = [[Intelsat]] | website = | COSPAR_ID = 1980-098A{{cite web|url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1980-098A|title=INTELSAT 5 F-2|publisher=National Space Science Data Center|accessdate=April 22, 2017}} | SATCAT = 12089 | mission_duration = 18 years | spacecraft_bus = [[Spacebus|Intelsat-V]] bus | manufacturer = [[Ford Aerospace]] | BOL_mass = {{convert|1012|kg|lb}} | launch_mass = {{convert|1928.2|kg|lb}} | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|06 December 1980, 23:31|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = [[Atlas-Centaur|Atlas SLV-3D Centaur-D1AR]] | launch_site = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Launch Complex 36|LC-36B]] | launch_contractor = | entered_service = | disposal_type = Decommissioned | deactivated = {{end-date|April 14, 1998}} | orbit_epoch = December 06, 1980 | orbit_reference = [[Geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Geostationary orbit|Geostationary]] | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|169|km}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|34834|km}} | orbit_inclination = 0 degrees | orbit_eccentricity = 0.72568 | orbit_period = 614.9 minutes | orbit_longitude = | apsis = gee | trans_band = 21 [[C band (IEEE)|C-band]]
4 {{Ku band}} | trans_frequency = | trans_capacity = | trans_coverage = | trans_TWTA = | trans_EIRP = | trans_HPBW = | programme = ''Intelsat V'' | previous_mission = [[Intelsat V F-1]] | next_mission = [[Intelsat V F-3]] }} '''Intelsat 502''', previously named '''Intelsat V F-2''', was a [[communications satellite]] operated by [[Intelsat]]. Launched in 1980, it was the second of fifteen [[Intelsat VI]] satellites to be launched. The Intelsat V series was constructed by [[Ford Aerospace]], based on the [[Spacebus|Intelsat-V]] [[satellite bus]]. Intelsat V F-2 was part of an advanced series of satellites designed to provide greater [[telecommunications]] capacity for [[Intelsat]]'s global network. The satellite was deactivated on April 14, 1998. The satellite was successfully launched into space on December 6, 1980, at 23:31 UTC, by means of an [[Atlas-Centaur|Atlas SLV-3D Centaur-D1AR]] vehicle from the [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]], [[Florida]], [[United States]]. It had a launch mass of 1,928 kg. The Intelsat 502 was equipped with 4 [[Ku-band]] transponders more 21 [[C band (IEEE)|C-band]] [[transponder]]s for 12,000 audio circuits and 2 TV channels. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Portal|Spaceflight}} {{Intelsat}} {{Orbital launches in 1980}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1980]] [[Category:Intelsat satellites]] [[Category:1980 in spaceflight]] {{US-spacecraft-stub}}

page.title: International Commission on Radiation Units and Measurements

revision.text:
The '''International Commission on Radiation Units and Measurements''' ('''ICRU''') is a standardization body set up in 1925 by the International Congress of Radiology, originally as the '''X-Ray Unit Committee''' until 1950. Its objective "is to develop concepts, definitions and recommendations for the use of [[physical quantity|quantities]] and their [[physical unit|unit]]s for [[radiation|ionizing radiation]] and its interaction with matter, in particular with respect to the biological effects induced by radiation".<ref>{{cite conference |conference = Occupational Radiation Protection: Protecting workers against exposure to ionising radiation |title = The ICRU: General Objectives and Achievements with regard to Occupational Radiation Protection |url = http://www-pub.iaea.org/MTCD/publications/PDF/Pub1145_web.pdf |first1 = A |last1 = Wambersie |first2 = HG |last2 = Menzel |pages = 99 - 110 |location = Geneva |date = 26–30 August 2002 |accessdate = 31 May 2012}}</ref>
The ICRU is a sister organisation to the [[International Commission on Radiological Protection]] (ICRP). In general terms the ICRU defines the units, and the ICRP recommends how they are used for [[radiation protection]].
==Development== During the first two decades of its existence, its formal meetings were held during the International Congress of Radiology, but from 1950 onwards, when its mandate was extended, it has met annually.
Until 1953, the president of the ICRU was a national of the country that was hosting the ICR, but in that year it was decided to elect a permanent commission - the first permanent chairman being [[Lauriston S. Taylor]] who had been a member of the commission since 1928 and secretary since 1934. Taylor served until 1969 and on his retirement was accorded the position of honorary chairman which we held until his death in 2004, aged 102.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.icrp.org/page.asp?id=92 |title = Emeritus and founder member L S Taylor dies |date = 1 December 2004 |publisher = International Commission on Radiological Protection |accessdate = 18 June 2012}}</ref>
In the late 1950s the ICRU was invited by the CGPM to join other scientific bodies to work with the [[International Committee for Weights and Measures]] (CIPM) in the development of a system of units that could be used consistently over many disciplines. This body, initially known as the "Commission for the System of Units" (renamed in 1964 as the "Consultative Committee for Units") was responsible overseeing the development of the [[International System of Units]] (SI).<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.bipm.org/en/committees/cc/ccu/ |title = CCU: Consultative Committee for Units |publisher = [[International Bureau of Weights and Measures]] (BIPM) |accessdate = 18 May 2012}}</ref>
In the late 1950s the ICRU started publishing reports on an irregular basis - on average two to three a year. In 2001 the publication cycle was regularised and reports are now published bi-annually under the banner "Journal of the ICRU".<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.icru.org/index.php?option=com_link_index&type=category&id=13&count=6&limit=6&limitstart=72 |title = Reports |publisher = International Commission on Radiation Units and Measurements |accessdate = 3 June 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.oxfordjournals.org/our_journals/jicru/about.html |title = Journal of the ICRU |accessdate = 3 June 2012 |year = 2012 |publisher = [[Oxford University Press]]}}</ref>
==Current operation== The commission has a maximum of fifteen members who serve for four years and who, since 1950, have been nominated by the incumbent commissioners. Members are selected for their scientific ability and is widely regarded as the foremost panel of experts in radiation medicine and in the other fields of ICRU endeavor. The commission is funded by the sale of reports, by grants from the [[European Commission]], the [[National Cancer Institute|US National Cancer Institute]] and the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]] and indirectly by organisations and companies who provide meeting venues. Commissioners, many of whom have full-time university or research centre appointments, have their expenses reimbursed, but otherwise they receive no remuneration from the ICRU.
==Radiation quantities== [[File:Dose_quantities_and_units.png|thumb|400px|External dose quantities used in radiation protection and dosimetry based on ICRU 57, jointly developed with the ICRP]] The commission has been responsible for defining and introducing many of the following units of measure. The number of different units for various quantities is indicative of changes of thinking in world metrology, especially the movement from [[Centimetre–gram–second system of units|cgs]] to [[International System of Units|SI]] units.<ref name = ICRUHistory>{{cite web |url = http://icru.org/images/pdf/icru_poster.pdf |title = International Commission on Radiation Units and Measurements |publisher = International Commission on Radiation Units and Measurements |date = 14 March 2012 |accessdate = 1 June 2012}}</ref>
The following table shows radiation quantities in SI and non-SI units.
{{Radiation related quantities}} Although the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission permits the use of the units [[curie]], rad, and [[rem (unit)|rem]] alongside SI units,<ref>{{cite book|title=10 CFR 20.1004|year=2009|publisher=US Nuclear Regulatory Commission|url=https://www.nrc.gov/reading-rm/doc-collections/cfr/part020/part020-1004.html}}</ref> the [[European Union]] [[European units of measurement directives]] required that their use for "public health ... purposes" be phased out by 31 December 1985.<ref>{{cite web
| url = http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:31980L0181:EN:NOT
| author = The Council of the European Communities
| title = Council Directive 80/181/EEC of 20 December 1979 on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to Unit of measurement and on the repeal of Directive 71/354/EEC
| date=1979-12-21
| accessdate=19 May 2012}}</ref>
==Administration== The Commission's secretariat is in Stockholm and its legal status is that of British [[Charitable organization|charity]] (Not-for-profit organisation).
==See also== *[[International Commission on Radiological Protection]] (ICRP) *[[Gray (unit)]] *[[International Radiation Protection Association]] (IRPA) *[[Radiation protection]] *[[Sievert]] ==Videos== * [[https://www.youtube.com/user/stralsakert| Video channel celebrating 90 years of the ICRP and ICRU]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.icru.org ICRU website] {{Radiation protection|state=uncollapsed}} [[Category:Radiology organizations]] [[Category:Standards organizations in Sweden]] [[Category:International medical and health organizations]]
[[Category:Radiation protection]]

{{multiple issues| {{notability|Products|date=February 2013}} {{primary sources|date=February 2013}} }} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2013}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:myTV (Arabic)}} {{Infobox company | name = myTV | logo = MyTV official logo.jpg | type = [[Corporation]], [[startup company|start-up]] | location = myTV_Inc.
3941 S. Bristol suite D282
Santa Ana CA 92704, US

myTV SAL
MGM building
5th Floor
Jal El-Dib Main Rd
Postal Code:2620 2501
[[Metn]], Lebanon | area_served = North America & South America | key_people = Spiro Azkoul (CEO){{cite web|url=http://www.linkedin.com/profile/view?id=45352752&authType=OUT_OF_NETWORK&authToken=50d5&trk=extra_biz_connect_hb_upphoto |title=Join |publisher=LinkedIn |date= |accessdate=2013-08-15}} | industry = Broadcast | products = [[Direct broadcast satellite]], [[Video on Demand]], [[Over-the-top content|OTT]] | foundation = [[Beirut, Lebanon]] (2011) | homepage = [http://my-tv.us www.my-tv.us] }} '''myTV''' is an [[Arab American]] provider of Arabic live channels and [[video on demand]] in North and South America, Australia and New Zealand, using [[Over-the-top content|over-the-top technology]]. ==History== myTV, an [[over-the-top content]] service provider with offices in Lebanon and the U.S., was founded on the June 15, 2011 by Lebanese expatriates living in the US.{{cite web|url=http://www.nowlebanon.com/NewsArticleDetails.aspx?ID=373336 |title=Bringing home TV back home |publisher=Nowlebanon.com |date=March 7, 2012 |accessdate=February 1, 2013}} The concept was originally developed by SNA Corp.http://www.snacorp.com {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140329000938/http://www.snacorp.com/ |date=March 29, 2014 }} a leading provider of Digital Online Content services for multinational media companies. MyTV provides Arabic-language Live TV Channels and Video on Demand (VOD) everywhere in the Americas as well as Europe, Australia and New Zealand. The myTV service helps expatriates and people-on-the-move feel closer to their homeland, by giving them access to the channels they love, and the TV shows, movies or music videos they miss, straight to their living room television set or mobile device.{{cite web|url=http://www.lecommercedulevant.com/node/20439 |title=MyTv, une chaîne 100% expatriés |publisher=lecommercedulevant.com |date=February 4, 2012 |accessdate=August 1, 2013}} In response to the demand for quality television in Arabic, myTV secured exclusive deals with the most popular channels such as LBC America and Rotana.{{cite web|url=http://www.zawya.com/story/LBC_America_back_to_the_TV_sets_of_Lebanese_Diaspora_in_North_and_South_America-ZAWYA20110617085508/ |title="LBC America" back to the TV sets of Lebanese Diaspora in North and South America |publisher=zawya.com |date=February 4, 2012 |accessdate=August 1, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://ucipliban.org/arabic/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=28573 |title=Ucip Liban |publisher=ucipliban.org |date=June 19, 2011 |accessdate=February 1, 2013}} ==Launch== myTV launched its services through an online campaign themed "Messages from Home" that began on January 30, 2012. The videos, composed of genuine messages gathered from [[Lebanese people]] across the country to their relatives abroad, were posted on [[Facebook]], [[YouTube]],{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e_6SYEMChjg&feature=g-upl |title=Messages from Lebanon |publisher=YouTube |date=June 1, 2012 |accessdate=February 1, 2013}} [[Twitter]] and [[Pinterest]]; these social platforms made up the bulk of online tools used during the campaign.{{cite web|last=Salti |first=Ramzi |url=http://author32.blogspot.com/2012/02/messages-from-lebanon-clever-video.html |title=Arabology: Cultural Productions from/about the Arab World: Messages from Lebanon: Clever Video Clips Courtesy of myTV (Lebanon/USA) |publisher=Author32.blogspot.com |date=February 5, 2012 |accessdate=February 1, 2013}} ==Recognition== In March 2013, [[Communicate Levant]], the [[Beirut]]-based [[sibling]] of market-leading [[Communicate magazine]], one of the region’s leading [[advertising]], [[marketing]] and [[media resource]], voted myTV as the number one startup for 2013.{{cite news |first=Levant |last=Communicate |title= 'Ten Homegrown start-ups' |page=28 |date=March 2013 |work=Communicate Levant |location = Beirut }} ==Features== ===Live Channels=== Channels currently available on myTV include[http://www.my-tv.us/Arabic-Channels myTV - Arabic Channels] * [[Lebanese Broadcasting Corporation|LBC America]] * [[Lebanese Broadcasting Corporation|LBC America Drama]] * [[Lebanese Broadcasting Corporation|LBC America News]] * [[Al Sumaria]] * [[Rotana Group|Rotana Khalijiah]] * [[Rotana Masriya]] * [[Al Jadeed]] * Fann * Safwa * Roya TV * Arab Woman TV * [[Al-Resalah Satellite TV|Al-Resalah]] * [[Iqraa TV|Iqraa]] * Taha TV * [[Iqraa TV|Iqraa Europe]] * [[Iqraa TV|Iqraa America]] * [[Iqraa TV|Iqraa Asia and Australia]] * [[Rotana Cinema]] * Cinema 1 * Cinema 2 * [[Rotana Aflam]] * [[Rotana Classic]] * Al Yawm * Al Mousalsalat * [[Rusiya Al-Yaum|Rusiya Al-Yawm]] * [[Sky News Arabia]] * [[BBC Arabic Television|BBC Arabic]] * [[ONTV (Egypt)|ONTV]] * [[Rotana Mousica|Rotana Music]] * [[Rotana (television)|Rotana Clip]] * Music Now * Karameesh ===Video on Demand=== myTV has an extensive [[Video on Demand]] library, consisting of Arabic movies, Arabic TV series, documentaries, cartoons and short films consisting of popular titles, such as the following: * A collection of [[Youssef Chahine]] films.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2013/film/news/global-village-brazil-builds-mega-studio-song-fest-has-europe-burning-more-1200488720/ |title=International news briefs: Industry highlights from around the world |publisher=Variety |date=May 29, 2013 |accessdate=August 2013}} * Lebanese classic TV series, such as ''[[Insa Hmoumak]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.my-tv.us/program/id/172 |title=myTV - Channels from home |publisher=My-tv.us |date= |accessdate=February 1, 2013}} and ''[[El Denieh hek]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.my-tv.us/program/id/171 |title=myTV - Channels from home |publisher=My-tv.us |date= |accessdate=February 1, 2013}} as well as [[musical film]]s by Lebanese singer [[Fairuz]]. * [[Umm Kulthum]]{{cite web|url=http://www.my-tv.us/program/id/151 |title=myTV - Channels from home |publisher=My-tv.us |date= |accessdate=February 1, 2013}} and [[Abdel Halim Hafez]]{{cite web|url=http://www.my-tv.us/program/id/105 |title=myTV - Channels from home |publisher=My-tv.us |date= |accessdate=February 1, 2013}} concerts. * Several works of the character Ghawwar el Tosheh ([[Duraid Lahham]]), such as Shaqaeq Al Noman,{{cite web|url=http://www.my-tv.us/program/id/260 |title=myTV - Channels from home |publisher=My-tv.us |date= |accessdate=February 1, 2013}} Day'et Tishrin,{{cite web|url=http://www.my-tv.us/program/id/264 |title=myTV - Channels from home |publisher=My-tv.us |date= |accessdate=February 1, 2013}} Hamam el Hana{{cite web|url=http://www.my-tv.us/program/id/265 |title=myTV - Channels from home |publisher=My-tv.us |date= |accessdate=February 1, 2013}} and Wein el Ghalat.{{cite web|url=http://www.my-tv.us/program/id/267 |title=myTV - Channels from home |publisher=My-tv.us |date= |accessdate=February 1, 2013}} * ''Al Shahroura'', the [[Ramadan]] TV series that tells the story of Lebanese singer [[Sabah]] and explores her artistic and personal life. A biography acted out by pop star [[Carole Samaha]]{{cite web|url=http://www.my-tv.us/Program/585/al-shahroura|title=Al Shahroura on myTV |publisher=my-tv.us |date= |accessdate=August 1, 2013}} * ''As the Poet Said'', a film that takes on a poetic approach to the life of the late Palestinian poet [[Mahmoud Darwish]].{{cite web|url=http://www.my-tv.us/program/id/87 |title=myTV - Channels from home |publisher=My-tv.us |date= |accessdate=February 1, 2013}} * Several historical series, telling the tales of [[Antarah ibn Shaddad]]{{cite web|url=http://www.my-tv.us/program/id/230 |title=myTV - Channels from home |publisher=My-tv.us |date= |accessdate=February 1, 2013}} and [[Khalid ibn al-Walid]].{{cite web|url=http://www.my-tv.us/program/id/228 |title=myTV - Channels from home |publisher=My-tv.us |date= |accessdate=February 1, 2013}} * Foreign Arabic-dubbed series, such as ''[[María la del Barrio]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.my-tv.us/program/id/193 |title=myTV - Channels from home |publisher=My-tv.us |date= |accessdate=February 1, 2013}} starring [[Thalía]] and [[Rosalinda (telenovela)|Rosalinda]]{{cite web|url=http://www.my-tv.us/program/id/189 |title=myTV - Channels from home |publisher=My-tv.us |date= |accessdate=February 1, 2013}} * A long list of [[anime]] cartoons dubbed (Arabic voice over) in Arabic, including ''[[Grendizer]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.my-tv.us/program/id/206 |title=myTV - Channels from home |publisher=My-tv.us |date= |accessdate=February 1, 2013}} ''[[Princess Sarah|Sally]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.my-tv.us/program/id/255 |title=myTV - Channels from home |publisher=My-tv.us |date= |accessdate=February 1, 2013}} ''[[Captain Tsubasa|Captain Majid]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.my-tv.us/Program/587/captain-majid |title=myTV - Channels from home | publisher=My-tv.us |accessdate=February 1, 2013}} and ''[[Calimero]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.my-tv.us/program/id/298 |title=myTV - Channels from home |publisher=My-tv.us |date= |accessdate=February 1, 2013}} * A series of the interpretation of the [[Quran]] by [[Muhammad Metwally Al Shaarawy|Sheikh Sha'arawi]]{{cite web|url=http://www.my-tv.us/program/id/73 |title=myTV - Channels from home |publisher=My-tv.us |date= |accessdate=February 1, 2013}} * A series of high-profile interviews with celebrities all over the world by renowned Lebanese host [[Ricardo Karam]]{{cite web|url=http://www.my-tv.us/Program/392/hadisson-akhar |title=myTV - Channels from home |publisher=My-tv.us |date= |accessdate=February 1, 2013}} ==Device support== As of 2013, myTV has become available on over 300 devices, which consist of set-top boxes, smart TVs and [[tablet computer|tablets]]. Some of the devices include: * [[Google TV]] devices{{cite web|url=https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=myTV.Android&feature=md|title=myTV app on Google TV|publisher=Googleplay |date= |accessdate=June 19, 2013}} [[Set-top box]]es like Sony Internet Player TV as well as [[Android (operating system)|Android]] and [[Samsung]] tablets. * [[Boxee Box]] set-top box{{cite web|url=http://www.my-tv.us/How-It-Works/ |title= myTV - How it works |publisher=my-tv.us |date= |accessdate=August 1, 2013}} * [[Samsung Smart TV]]{{cite web|url=http://www.samsung.com/us/appstore/app/G00005314410 |title=Appstore Overview - myTV G00005314410 | Samsung TV & Blu-ray Apps |publisher=Samsung.com |date= |accessdate=February 1, 2013}} * LG SMART TV (only 47G2 and 55G2 Models) * [[WD TV]] Live{{cite web|url=http://www.wdc.com/en/products/products.aspx?id=330 |title=WD TV Live |publisher=Wdc.com |date= |accessdate=February 1, 2013}} * [[Netgear]] Neo TV 300 ==See also== [[Internet Television]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== *{{Official website|1=http://www.my-tv.us}} [[Over-the-top content|OTT]] {{DEFAULTSORT:myTV}} [[Category:Media companies of the United Arab Emirates]] [[Category:Direct broadcast satellite services]] [[Category:Television technology]] [[Category:Video on demand services]] [[Category:Media companies established in 2011]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox musical artist | name = Olia Tira | image = Olia Tira.jpg | caption = Olia Tira in Oslo 2010 | background = solo_singer | alias = FLUX LIGHT | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1988|8|1|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Potsdam]], [[East Germany]] | death_date = | origin = [[Chişinău]], [[Moldova]] | genre = [[Pop music|Pop]], [[Electronic dance music|dance]] funk | occupation = [[Singing|Singer]] | years_active = 2003–present | label = | associated_acts = [[SunStroke Project]] | website = }} '''Olia Tira''' (born 1 August 1988 in [[Potsdam]], [[East Germany]]), also known by her [[stage name]] '''FLUX LIGHT''', is a [[Moldova|Moldovan]] singer. ==Early life== Tira was born in 1988 into a [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] military family{{Cite web | title =evenimente: Olia Tira, cântăreaţa care sparge stereotipurile | work =Muzica Md | publisher =Imco | date =2 February 2007 | url =http://muzica.md/news.php?nid=1465 | accessdate =21 April 2010 | deadurl =yes | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20110722170926/http://muzica.md/news.php?nid=1465 | archivedate =22 July 2011 | df = }} in [[Potsdam]], [[East Germany]].{{Cite web| title =Moldova – "Sun Stroke Project" & Olia Tira | work =Eurovision Song Contest Oslo 2010 | publisher =Eurovision Georgia | year =2010 | url =http://www.eurovision-georgia.ge/participants/Moldova.aspx?LanguageID=2 | accessdate =21 April 2010 }} She spent a few years there and moved to [[Chişinău]]. She first appeared in festivals and concerts when she was 14 years old.{{Cite web| last =Floras | first =Stella | title =The Olia Tira interview | work =Special | publisher =ESCToday | date =9 December 2007 | url =http://www.esctoday.com/specials/read/9838 | accessdate =21 April 2010 }} Tira attended school in [[Cahul]] and is currently a student in the [[Academy of Music, Theatre and Fine Arts]] in Chişinău. Tira's first album, ''Your Place or Mine?'', was released in December 2006 by Nordika Multimedia. The songs were all written by [[Ruslan Taranu]]. ==Eurovision Song Contest== After participating in the 2006 and 2007 Moldovan national finals and finishing fourth in the 2009 Moldovan national final with ''Unicul Meu'', she was selected to represent [[Moldova in the Eurovision Song Contest 2010|Moldova in the]] [[Eurovision Song Contest 2010]], along with [[SunStroke Project]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=10103&_t=Sun+Stroke+Project+%26+Olia+Tira+for+Moldova!|title=Sun Stroke Project & Olia Tira for Moldova!|last=Brey|first=Marco|date=6 March 2010|publisher=''[[European Broadcasting Union]]''|accessdate=6 March 2010}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/15314|title=Moldova sends Sunstroke Project & Olia Tira to Eurovision|last=Klier|first=Marcus|date=6 March 2010|publisher=''ESCToday''|accessdate=6 March 2010}} They finished 22nd in the Eurovision Song Contest final. She was a finalist in [[Moldova in the Eurovision Song Contest 2014|O melodie pentru europa 2014]], [[Moldova|Moldova's]] national selection for the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2014]] with the song "Never Stop No". She competed under the [[stage name]], FLUX LIGHT.{{Cite web|url=http://wiwibloggs.com/2014/02/07/moldova-olia-tira-undercover-o-melodie-pentru-europa/38826/|title=MOLDOVA: OLIA TIRA WAS UNDERCOVER AT O MELODIE PENTRU EUROPA |last=Honciuc|first=Bogdan|date=6 February 2014|publisher=Wiwibloggs.com|accessdate=6 February 2014}} She tied for sixth place and did not qualify to represent Moldova. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{S-start}} {{S-ach}} {{Succession box| before=[[Nelly Ciobanu]]
with ''[[Hora Din Moldova]]'' | title=[[Moldova in the Eurovision Song Contest]] | years=(with [[SunStroke Project]])
[[Eurovision Song Contest 2010|2010]]| after=[[Zdob şi Zdub]]
with ''[[So Lucky (Zdob şi Zdub song)|So Lucky]]'' }} {{S-end}} {{Moldova in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{Commons category}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tira, Olia}} [[Category:1988 births]] [[Category:Eurovision Song Contest entrants of 2010]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Moldovan Eurovision Song Contest entrants]] [[Category:People from Potsdam]] [[Category:People from Chișinău]] [[Category:Moldovan female singers]] [[Category:Moldovan expatriates in Germany]] [[Category:Soviet expatriates in Germany]] {{Moldova-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=March 2013}}[[File:Strong white on blue.jpg|thumb|Strong Australia logo|right]] {{Advert|date=April 2018}} '''Strong Australia''' is a [[consumer electronics]] manufacturer that supplies broadcasting receivers and other video and audio related apparatus. Their main business is making products for use in Australia such as [[set-top box|set top boxes (STBs)]] and [[personal video recorder|personal video recorders (PVRs)]] to be used with [[satellite television]] or [[digital television]]. Strong Australia in recent times have been manufacturing Android media players and IPTV products to expand their lineup.
The company has a head office in [[Melbourne]], Australia, and its parent company Strong Technologies bases its operations in the Middle East and Africa.
== Personal Video Recorder == Strong Australia produces PVRs for [[High-definition television|standard- and high-definition]] television program recording. The PVRs store the digital files in a container-format with the .TS [[file extension]] on their hard-disk drives or on external drives via [[USB]]; software updates are provided on their website which include fixes and improvements on both previous and current models.
== Media Players == Since 2012, Strong Australia have been introducing Android-based media players to the [[Australia]]n retail market in the form of [[set-top box|set top boxes]]. Beginning with the SRT AN4, this was the first media player available in the Australian market with an [[Android (operating system)|Android]] based operating system running [[Android Ice Cream Sandwich|Ice Cream Sandwich]] which also included a [[DVB-T2]] terrestrial tuner for the viewing of live television. The SRT AN4M model is the same without including the [[DVB-T2]] tuner. Both units use a [[Telechips|Telechips TCC892x]] CPU with 1GB of RAM, two [[USB|USB 2.0 ports]], a coaxial audio out port for digital audio output and one HDMI output.
== Rock-Box ==
[[Rock-Box]] is the name of Strong Australia's more recent Android media player series, with two different models including the SRT RB2 and SRT RB4. Both models run [[Android Jelly Bean|Android 4.2 Jelly Bean]] and use [[Rockchip|Rockchip RK3066 and RK3188 processors]], a selection of dual and quad core chips relating to the names of the Rock-Box model numbers (SRT RB2 - Dual core, SRT RB-4 - Quad core).
The key differences between the SRT RB2 and SRT RB4 along with their chipset differences are as follows:
*SRT RB2 has 1GB of RAM and 8GB of [[Flash memory#NAND flash|NAND]] storage *SRT RB4 has 2GB of RAM and 16GB of [[Flash memory#NAND flash|NAND]] storage
Both models use the same [[Mali (GPU)|Mali-400 GPU]] although the GPU inside the SRT RB4 is clocked slightly higher as a result of the quad core processor. [[Wi-Fi|2.4GHz Wi-Fi]] with external antenna, [[Bluetooth]], [[Secure Digital#Micro|MicroSD]] card reader and four [[USB|USB 2.0 ports]] make it a suitable media player for different applications and will accept common external hard drives with formats including but not limited to [[File Allocation Table#FAT32|FAT 32]] and [[NTFS]] as well as USB mice or keyboards, both wired and wireless.
These products come with the stock Android applications installed as well as the [[Netflix]], [[Hulu]] and [[Kodi (software)|XBMC]] applications. There is no skin or aesthetic changes on the version of Android in place on the Rock-Box products so it is a pure image of Android with minor tweaks for the set top box format.
== Models == A complete list of models is available on the Strong Australia website * SRT 6100 * SRT 6500 * SRT 7014 * SRT 4922B+ * SRT 4950H * SRT AN4 * SRT AN4M * SRT RB2 * SRT RB4 * SRT MPT
